questions.text:
Which of the following is the **highest common factor (HCF)** of 'K' and 'M'?
Factors of $$K = 3^{3} 	imes 2^{2}$$
Factors of $$M = 3^{2} 	imes 2^{3}$$
questions.solution:
$$HCF = 2^{2} 	imes 3^{2} = 4 	imes 9 = 36$$
Hence, option B is correct.

questions.text: Find the **least common multiple (LCM)** of two numbers whose factors are $$(x^{3} 	imes y^{5})$$ and $$(x^{2} 	imes y^{2})$$ respectively.
questions.solution:
$$LCM = x^{3} 	imes y^{5}$$
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is **false**?
options: Product of 18 and 16 is equal to the product of its LCM and HCF
Product of 12, 14 and 20 is equal to the product of their LCM and HCF
HCF cannot be more than LCM
More than one option is false
questions.solution:
**Option B is incorrect.** 
Product of three numbers is not always equal to the products of their HCF and LCM. The product of three numbers can be equal to the product of their HCF and LCM only when the numbers are **prime numbers**.

questions.text: If the **HCF and LCM** of 'a' and 22 is **2** and **264** respectively, then find the value of **'a'**.
questions.solution:
$$HCF 	imes LCM = a 	imes 22$$
$$2 	imes 264 = 22a$$
$$a = 24$$
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: If the **product of two numbers** is equal to $$(x+22)$$ and **LCM** is also equal to the product of the numbers, then find the **HCF** of the two numbers.
questions.solution:
$$HCF 	imes LCM = \text{Product of two numbers}$$
Since LCM is also equal to the product of the numbers, in this case, HCF is always equal to **1**.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: The **LCM** of two numbers is $$(3x+3)$$ and the **HCF** of the same two numbers is **8**. If the **product of the numbers** is equal to **384**, then find the value of **'x'**.
questions.solution:
$$HCF 	imes LCM = \text{Product of two numbers}$$
$$(3x+3) \times 8 = 384$$
$$3x + 3 = 48$$
$$x = 45 / 3 = 15$$
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: If the **sum of two numbers** is **330** and their **HCF** is equal to **22**, then find which of the following options can be correct values for the two numbers.
questions.solution:
Let the numbers be $$22a$$ and $$22b$$.
$$22a + 22b = 330 \Rightarrow a + b = 330 / 22 = 15$$
Option A (176, 154) satisfies this: $$176/22 = 8$$ and $$154/22 = 7$$. Since $$8+7=15$$ and $$HCF(8,7)=1$$, it is correct.

questions.text: The **difference between 56 and 72** is equal to **A**. Find which of the following options can divide **A** and leave no remainder.
questions.solution:
$$\text{Difference of 56 and 72} = 16$$
16 is divisible by **8, 1, and 2**.
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text: If **'X'** is the highest number which divides **63, 112, and 154**, and leaves remainders equal to **3, 2, and 4** respectively, then find the value of **'X'**.
questions.solution:
$$X = HCF \text{ of } (63-3), (112-2), (154-4)$$
$$X = HCF(60, 110, 150) = 10$$
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text: Which of the given options is the **highest number** which divides **46, 94, and 158**, and leaves the **same remainder** in each case?
questions.solution:
Let the remainder be R. The HCF of $$(46-R), (94-R), (158-R)$$ is equal to the HCF of the differences between the numbers.
$$\text{Differences} = (94-46), (158-94), (158-46)$$
$$\text{Differences} = 48, 64, 112$$
$$HCF(48, 64, 112) = 16$$
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: Find the **least number** which when divided by **20, 22, and 28**, leaves a **remainder equal to 3** in all cases.
questions.solution:
$$LCM(20, 22, 28) = 1540$$
$$\text{Required Number} = 1540 + 3 = 1543$$
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: If **'M'** is the **least number** which when divided by **4, 6, and 8**, leaves a **remainder of 2** in each case, and if we divide **'M' by 16**, it gives **no remainder**. Find the value of **'M'**.
questions.solution:
$$LCM(4, 6, 8) = 24$$
To make remainder 2 in each case, the number is of form $$24k + 2$$.
Checking multiples: $$24(1)+2=26$$ (not div by 16). The multiple of 26 which is completely divisible by 16 is **208**.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: Find the **least possible number** which when divided by **12, 15, and 18**, leaves **1, 4, and 7** as remainders respectively.
questions.solution:
Difference between divisor and remainder is constant: 
$$12-1 = 11, 15-4 = 11, 18-7 = 11$$
$$LCM(12, 15, 18) = 180$$
$$\text{Required Number} = 180 - 11 = 169$$
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: Find the **least possible number** which when divided by **17** leaves a **remainder of 3** and when divided by **6** it leaves a **remainder of 2**.
questions.solution:
Let the dividend be D.
Case 1: $$D = 17x + 3$$
Case 2: $$D = 6y + 2$$
Equating both: $$17x + 3 = 6y + 2 \Rightarrow (17x + 1) / 6 = y$$
If $$x = 1$$, then $$y = 18 / 6 = 3$$
$$D = 17(1) + 3 = 20$$
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: If **three bells** ring every **3 seconds, 5 seconds, and 6 seconds** respectively, then find the time after which all three bells will **ring together**.
questions.solution:
$$LCM(3, 5, 6) = 30 \text{ seconds}$$
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: Find the **18th term** of an increasing **Arithmetic Progression (AP)** whose difference between two consecutive terms is **9** and the **first term** is **7**.
In an **Arithmetic Progression**, the **first term** and **last term** are **264** and **736** respectively. If there are **30 terms** in the progression, find the **sum of all terms**.
questions.solution:
$$\text{Sum} = \frac{n}{2} \times (1^{\text{st}} \text{ term} + \text{last term})$$
$$\text{Sum} = \frac{30}{2} \times (264 + 736)$$
$$\text{Sum} = 15 \times 1000 = 15000$$
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: If the **sum of 5 terms** of an AP is $$(x+10)$$, the **1st term** is **2**, and the **5th term** is $$(x-22)$$, find the value of **'x'**.
questions.solution:
$$\text{Sum} = \frac{n}{2} \times (a + l)$$
$$x + 10 = \frac{5}{2} \times (2 + x - 22)$$
$$2x + 20 = 5x - 100$$
$$3x = 120 \Rightarrow x = 40$$
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: If there are $$(x+5)$$ terms in an increasing AP, the **first term** is **3**, the **last term** is **59**, and the **common difference** is **4**, then find the value of **'x'**.
questions.solution:
$$T_{n} = a + (n - 1)d$$
$$59 = 3 + (x + 5 - 1) \times 4$$
$$56 = (x + 4) \times 4$$
$$x + 4 = 14 \Rightarrow x = 10$$
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: If the **last term** of an increasing AP is **40** and the **first term** is **10%** of the last term, find the possible **common difference** if the number of terms is **less than 10**.
questions.solution:
$$l = 40$$, $$a = 10\% \text{ of } 40 = 4$$
$$l = a + (n - 1)d \Rightarrow 40 = 4 + (n - 1)d \Rightarrow 36 = (n - 1)d$$
If we take $$n = 7$$ (which is < 10):
$$36 = (7 - 1)d \Rightarrow 6d = 36 \Rightarrow d = 6$$
Hence, option A is correct.
